Speaker.P: I rise to a point of order. There were a number of speeches delivered here that took up a considerable time and there are several Deputies who had no opportunity of expressing their views on this particular matter.
I was given to understand that it was the desire of the Minister to conclude at 8 o'clock, and my own experience tells me that it will be a matter of very great difficulty.

After the eloquent speech delivered by Deputy Mícheál O Cléirigh, which practically spilled the beans on everything I was going to say the House need not be afraid that I am going to detain them very long. A tame poet, a few moments ago, sent me across a little screed which it might be worth while quoting as a sort of introduction to the sermon which is about to be delivered:
“From year unto year
In the ocean's blue rim,
His beautiful promise
Showed lovely but dim.”

MainHeading.P: I am very much afraid that apathy describes the Department of Fisheries, this year in particular. The figures that were quoted here in the course of the debate proved conclusively, to me anyhow, that any little hope I had of re-organisation on a proper business footing of the Irish fishing industry does not lie with the present Department of Fisheries. Any possibility there was for the re-organisation of that industry and for the giving of any hope to the unfortunate fishermen on the seaboard of this country and of dispelling the cloud of despair that seems to hang over them, certainly will not come from this Department as exemplified in the speech delivered here to-day by the Minister for Fisheries. Last year, when speaking on this Vote, I expressed my sympathy with the Department in that it had not been given enough money to perform its functions. None of the suggestions made on that occasion in good faith seems to call for comment. The Minister has achieved the distinction of drawing the finest red-herring across the trail of the debate.

The Minister has succeeded in spending nearly half an hour in dealing with everything but the Estimate. As Deputy Mícheál O Cléirigh said, it is time we came down to the facts and came back to the Estimate we are supposed to vote for or against in this House to-day. The facts are these. In the five years from 1925-26 to 1929-30 the two important items in the Department of Fisheries Estimate have shown a steady and unceasing decrease. For fishery development in 1925-26 there was a total of £39,225; in 1926-27 it had gone down to £34,000; in 1927-28 it went down to £27,000; in 1928-29 it went down to £22,000, and this year it is £18,330. The same thing applies to the Estimate for rural industries for the last four years, with the exception of this year, where there is a very slight increase. It just struck me in examining this Estimate for the Department of Fisheries this year for the whole of the Free State that the sum total of £18,330 for fishery development compares very badly with the £40,000 spent by the old Congested Districts Board in the Gaeltacht counties alone, in the year 1912-13. It speaks badly for a Department set up by a so-called independent Irish Government, in an Irish independent, so-called, State. If there was any hope from this Department of Fisheries, if the people of the Gaeltacht were to receive any inspiration, I do not think they would find it in the speech delivered by the Minister in introducing this Estimate. Certainly it was a grand series of promises and an exhibition of a man with Aladdin's wonderful lamp trying to produce all the wonderful miracles Aladdin was alleged to have produced. The Minister has not referred to the fact that in 1928 the imports of fish into the Irish Free State were £150,283. In the five months of 1929 the imports were £161,436, whilst the exports for the corresponding five months of this year have decreased. Last year, in the debate for External Affairs, I think I made a suggestion to the Minister in charge of that Department that steps should be taken by our foreign consular service to open up diplomatic relations with the Soviet Government with a view to providing markets. I think that suggestion was sneered at. The Minister said our foreign representatives could not be made commercial travellers to sell fish, but the representatives of a greater and more powerful Government than this consider it a primary question to resume relations with a view to capturing markets.

Speaker.P: Which Government?
The Government of the British Commonwealth of Nations, otherwise known as the British Empire, of which this State is a component part.
Is this a matter for the Minister for External Affairs?
It has got a tremendous lot to do with fish.
The mention of the word “fish” is not sufficient to make it in order. The question of the resumption of relations with any other State is irrelevant here.

I was just leading up to the point that the best market for our fish, as stated in the report of a Committee that was set up and known as the report of the Imperial Economic Committee on the marketing and preparing for market of foodstuffs produced within the Empire—Fifth Report, Fish—was the market in Central and Eastern Europe, and that it was the only market which was capable of developing apart from the British nation itself.

MainHeading.P: I was pointing out that the Department of Fisheries at the present moment is responsible for the Gaeltacht areas under its control and it is supposed to have a Minister in this House prepared to answer questions as to conditions, economic and otherwise, in the Gaeltacht. If the Minister, instead of producing the series of promises which he produced last year, could give us any indication that an effort was about to be made to revive the fast dwindling industry that we have on our seaboard, and to secure even a partial market for the cured herrings which on the admission of foreign importers are amongst the best produced in Europe, it would be much more advisable. If he had given us some indication that steps would be taken to secure those things, there might be some possibility of giving him a little further time and some credence, but I am afraid that is not possible in the circumstances. He mentioned that further legislation was necessary in connection with territorial waters. Last year the same thing was mentioned and I think in the year preceding the same proposition was put before the House. When he was introducing the Estimate both last year and this year the Minister mentioned that he would shortly introduce a Bill. A Bill for a good many things has been a long time coming and this item of extra territorial jurisdiction is one which should long ago have engaged the attention of the Department of Fisheries and the Department of External Affairs.

Deputy Cassidy mentioned that poaching in Donegal has been going on continuously, and particularly during the last twelve or eighteen months. The same thing applies to West Cork. The patrol boat, which has been described as a fishery protection cruiser and which has been costing £8,000 per annum for the last six years, could not in the nature of things give satisfaction with a seaboard such as the Free State has. The suggestion was made last year that it might be far more profitable if some of the rum chasers that the American Government employ for the purposes of enforcing prohibition were procured in order to deal with the poachers. In reply to that suggestion the Minister promised another cruiser, but that promise has not materialised. I suggest seriously that he should take into consideration the possibility of negotiating with the Army Air Corps and see whether it would not be possible to substitute a few decent seaplanes for the Bristol bombing planes they have and these seaplanes could be utilised for the purpose of protecting Irish fisheries instead of cruisers of the “Muirchu” type.

I suggest that the Minister should give some more information as to the establishment of the Sea Fisheries Co-operative Association. I was glad when he mentioned that, and I thought it was some indication of returning sanity on the part of his Department, but now I am beginning to see the snag in the proposal. The Minister said that a reduction in the Estimate was accounted for by the elimination of £1,100 estimated last year for the organisation of fishermen. What is this new Co-operative Association going to cost? How does the Minister propose to go about its re-establishment? Is it to be a local or purely a national organisation? Is it to be controlled directly or indirectly by the Department? What voice will fishermen have in its control and direction? Some additional information should be given on the statement that boats would be supplied to competent fishermen. I know some competent fishermen who have been endeavouring to secure boats for a long time but up to the present there is no possibility of securing those boats. I am afraid that under the present regulations there will not be much possibility either. I would like to know how that scheme will operate in areas where no security can be found. There are very few areas where security can be got for the provision of boats and gear.

I would like to know something about the insurance scheme that the Minister mentioned. Will it be a comprehensive scheme? Is it going to include the insurance of the crews? How will this scheme of allocation in connection with each catch work out? How will the shares of each catch be distributed as between the Department of Fisheries and the fisherman-owner of the boat? Mention was made of a revaluation of boats and gear and the Minister stated that the Committee set up to inquire into the £120,000 arrears of loans due on boats was working actively and was going to take into consideration each individual case.

I seriously suggest that he should take his courage in his hands and come to the Dáil honestly and openly, irrespective of whether it will create a sensation in the House or not, and declare that he is going to stop tinkering with this problem, that he will admit he cannot collect the arrears and that it is physically impossible for the fishermen to pay, and in the circumstances that he is prepared to wipe out the arrears in 98 per cent. of the cases. I will give the Minister a few cases later on to prove that delay in the consideration of many cases has resulted in a considerable amount of hardship to fishermen, particularly along the west coast. There is one portion of the Report of the Economic Committee set up by the Imperial Conference which I would like to quote: “A vigorous handling of the difficulties of education and marketing, such as we have recently witnessed in the reorganisation of the Free State dairying industry, should enable the Irish Free State, situated as it is in the midst of good fishing grounds, well supplied with harbours and at no great distance from big markets, to take far more nearly its due share of the fishing harvest around its shores than it has so far succeeded in doing.”

The Minister should be able to produce some comprehensive scheme for consideration here. I am not going into the minor points with regard to piers, slips and harbours. I regret to notice that there is a decrease in the Estimate in respect to those things. The thing that forces me to the belief that this Vote should be referred back is the conclusion I have come to that the Executive Council are not serious in their desire to assist the fishing industry and are not serious in their desire to put into effect the recommendations of the Gaeltacht Commission. It would be far more honest to abolish the Department of Fisheries altogether. Under the present Government there appears to be little hope of saving the Irish fishing industry, and there appears to be little hope of saving the last stronghold of the Irish language, the Gaeltacht. It would be much better for the Government to abolish the Department entirely rather than to be tinkering with this problem by way of granting a few thousand pounds each year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. Sheehy Mr. T. Sheehy
Speaker.P: (Cork): I listened to-day with great interest to a number of speeches that were carefully read out to the House by the Opposition Deputies. I expected that these speeches would contain new programmes or reveal some progress of ideas in connection with deep-sea fishing. They contained nothing but a severe criticism of the Minister for Fisheries and his Department. I will not use a stronger term than that. I would wish to remind this House seriously to-day that we are discussing one of the most important industries associated with our nation. I have some recollections of the fishing industry. I was myself connected side by side with the father and brother of Deputy Hugo Flinn in the year 1882 in the mackerel fishing in the South of Ireland. At that time there were Irish boats and Irish skilled captains who were able to win the golden harvest from the deep.

MainHeading.P: But Deputies must remember that a vast change has taken place in the last half century. Those nations that were able to rule themselves and had the full command of the money raised by their own Government developed their fisheries in those years. They were given grants for improved boats. Our fishermen, unfortunately, in those far-off days had to work in miserable boats. No Government cared anything whether they would win or lose. So bad at that time was the outlook that a great priest, Father Davis, went over to London and appealed to an English lady, the Baroness Burdett-Coutts, to come to the rescue of the unfortunate Cape Clear fishermen in his parish. It was useless to appeal to the Government that ruled in this country at the time. But his appeal was listened to by that good lady. The Baroness Burdett-Courts advanced some thousands of pounds without any interest whatever for the purpose of procuring boats for our local fishermen at Cape Clear. That aid heartened and encouraged the fishermen in winning a living from the deep. Before that they had been looking from their hillsides at the fishermen from the Isle of Man and the fishermen from England and France carrying away from their very doors the golden harvest of the deep while they, with their families, stood by in despair and with bad conditions all round them.

Through the years the fishery industry struggled, and at a later period the Congested Districts Board came along and helped the fishermen. In this very House, as a member of the Council of Agriculture and Fisheries, I proposed many a resolution asking that more should be done to help the fishermen, but it was all in vain very often. Those in authority at that time were only concerned with cattle and the development of horse-breeding. I could scarcely get an audience to listen to me when I was appealing for generous treatment for the fishermen.

But coming down now to our own day, thank God I am addressing the representatives of the Irish nation. No amount of pessimism and criticism of that kind from the other side will wipe out that fact. In the words of a very distinguished American that I met to-day as I was coming to this House——

Speaker.P: Oh, now.

Very well, I will come back to fishing. Since I entered the Dáil two years ago I have heard nothing from the Opposition with regard to fisheries and the fishing industry but the most adverse criticism of the Government. The Government have been accused of the omissions and the things that were done wrong, and the results of these in the years before they took over this country from the old régime. The magic wand of the Minister for Fisheries was to change all that at once. No doubt whatever, if during the last year or two the Minister had a united House behind him he would have done better work for the fishing industry. If the Deputies on the Opposition side put politics on one side and joined like one man and tried to bring back the fishing industry to the state of prosperity in which that industry once was, it would be much better for the House and for the country.

MainHeading.P: What do we find here to-day? Where is the programme for the improvement of the fishing industry? Where is the idea put forward to secure steam trawlers that would compete with the English trawlers? Here in Dublin, and I am speaking particularly now to the Government Deputies, you have the good luck to have a plucky energetic company sending a number of trawlers fishing into the deep seas. They have seven steam trawlers at a cost of £3,000 or £4,000 each. On these trawlers there is only one Irish captain, and I am glad to say he is from my constituency. I hope that when the Minister for Fisheries is looking for experts for his Committee that he will put Captain Coughlan on it. Deputies need not laugh nor smile now because Captain Coughlan has a wide experience of the fishing industry from Iceland to Germany and down to North Africa. He is the competent captain of one of these steam trawlers. He is the man who taught the Icelanders for a company in Iceland how to fish some years ago. He is in the prime of life. He is the captain of the latest boat that has been added to their fishing fleet. He tells me that there is immense wealth to be earned by the Irish people if the Deputies here made a proper gesture, and if we would provide five more steam trawlers they would be needed to supply the fish for Dublin alone. We ought to go farther. Support instead of criticism ought to be given to the Government. What are they getting? I heard Deputy Cassidy discussing this matter to-day. That Deputy talked about forestry last week and he voted against the Forestry Estimate. If that Deputy had his way there would be no men employed in forestry to-day, because there would be no money available to pay them. Really that is not the way to build up a great national industry. Let Deputies come here with some constructive policy and some constructive ideas and place them before the House.

Now, if we had five more steam trawlers we could supply Dublin with fish. I look to the time when we will have a quarter-million more people here in Dublin. I will have passed away then, but I have no doubt that in not so many years from now there will be a quarter of a million more people in Dublin, and in that number alone there will be a huge market for the fish caught along our shore. The Government is not getting the proper encouragement from the Opposition sections here in this House. It is only from the Independent Deputies that the Government can get the support that is deserved. I bow to them as decent men. Since I came here I have seen them loyally sticking to their oaths and supporting and encouraging every practical movement that is brought forward for the betterment of the country. I am glad to say that for them; I am under no obligation to them, but as honest Irishmen it is a pleasure to us to see them here shouldering the burden side by side with us.

I have no doubt that there is great hope for our deep-sea fisheries. Down in Cork I see the French with their lobster boats. They come along with improved boats that are capable of carrying five men each to the sea, and they have very suitable accommodation on board. What facilities for lobster fishing have the men of Hare Island? There are only three of them in a little boat, and they have only a sail to protect them when they go to Waterford or Wexford.

I am glad that Mr. Lynch, the Minister, is setting up this Committee on which there will be experts. The Minister also stated that there will be money behind it. That is the first great need for the building up of the fisheries. Money is required and it is not the miserable criticism that we hear here and the tinkering and sneering that is to build up our nation. Let us put politics aside and let us approach these great economic questions and we will win prosperity for the country. If we work together we will be all right. Some Deputies here are so obsessed with politics that they think that because President Cosgrave and his Government is in office that nothing can be right. Nothing will please some Deputies here. As far as the Government is concerned, I would ask them to provide plenty of money to get the best experts that the Saorstát can supply in the way of skilled fishermen.

To encourage that Committee I would make this suggestion now, that during the Recess Mr. Lynch, the Minister for Fisheries, and Deputy Lemass would go on a trip on one of those Dublin steam trawlers and see how the work of the fishermen is being done. They would come back with some knowledge of fisheries. They would come back with a practical knowledge of the work; they would in that trip learn a great deal about the business. It is in that way by taking up this matter in a big way that we are going to make this country great and prosperous.

Speaker.P: I would support the views of Deputy Sheehy in advocating that a larger sum be given to the Ministry of Fisheries. Complaints against the Fisheries Department are more or less hardy annuals but there are just a few questions I desire to put to the Minister. First of all, I would like to know whether there will be any representatives of the fishermen's organisation on the new Committee to be set up in regard to revaluation of boats. Pending the decisions of that Committee will the Minister postpone the execution of such decrees as he has already got against the fishermen? In Arklow there are a number of such decrees. The Fisheries Department are urged by the Department of Finance to take proceedings against these men who, through no fault of their own but through stress of weather and other causes, have lost their nets and other gear. The Department got decrees against them for the full amount and I urge the Minister not to execute them pending the decisions of the new Committee. If some people are going to be let off by 50 per cent. or the amount they paid in 1914, the men to whom I refer should not be charged a full hundred per cent.

MainHeading.P: Further, I would like to know whether the recommendation to have a training school in Arklow will be carried out. I also agree with Deputy Sheehy in saying that until we supply the fishermen with boats and gear similar to those used by the fishermen in Scotland, France and Belgium we will not be able to compete with the foreigners who come within the three mile limit and take our fish. Perhaps the Committee would also consider the hardship caused to a number of fishermen who had to pay many calls owing to insurance while they got very little in return. I ask the Minister to take into consideration the excess amount which these men paid through insurance and so forth. The Minister should also consider the question of improving the transport of fish. At present the fishermen get very little for their share of the catch, while the dealers and hawkers get practically all the benefit. The men who often risk their lives to get fish get practically nothing out of it. There should be a quick and efficient transport to the inland towns, where a taste for fish could be developed. Consumers would then pay lower prices than they are now paying while the fishermen would get better returns. Again I would press on the Minister's consideration the claims of those who are now unable to purchase nets, as they lost those which they had in former years, and also owing to the fact that persons who acted as sureties for them are now acting for others. Under the new scheme for loans the men should, as I say, be given better boats, better engines and better gear in every way in order to prevent foreign trawlers from taking our fish within the three mile limit.

Speaker.P: I have admiration for the Minister for Fisheries and for the officials who work under him. I believe that the Fianna Fáil Deputies really have a grádh for them in the depths of their hearts. At all times, when I approached them on any topic or scheme that would be of benefit to the fishing folk in my part of the country, I found them most willing and obliging, and invariably what I asked was done. In Helvic Harbour they erected beacons and also gave facilities for curing operations. In Ballinagown they supplied the fishermen with boxes and otherwise helped them to get better prices for their fish. Small motor craft have been supplied to many persons in Waterford under the loans system, and I understand that the advances are being well repaid. If the efforts towards co-operation which are now being made are brought to a conclusion, the Waterford fishermen should represent the nucleus of a good local branch in the general co-operative movement. In regard to loans to fishermen, unhappily, when they go to fish they are not always successful. I know several places in Waterford where men have obtained loans from the Fisheries Department, but, owing to the scarcity or complete absence of fish, they find it very hard to meet their liabilities to the Department. In some of these cases where loans were issued, guarantors came forward. I think that where it can be proved that the fisherman has worked honestly —if necessary that could be verified by the Civic Guards—the Department should deal leniently with him and his guarantor.

I believe that the cardinal problem that faces the inland fisheries— I mean fisheries within the three-mile limit—is the question of effective protection. I know the “Muirchú,” the old “Helga,” but I am afraid that she is not able to patrol the entire coast-line. When you recollect that the coast-line around Cork extends for 300 miles, you can realise the length of the Saorstát coast-line. I think that it is essential to the whole question of fisheries that additional vessels should be acquired. About twenty years ago, I remember a Danish training ship coming into Waterford having on board between thirty and forty cadets who were being taught everything about fishing and seamanship. If a couple of vessels of that kind were acquired for the Saorstát, I think that not only would these pupils learn their duties as fishermen, but they would form the nucleus of what I hope to see one day, namely, an Irish mercantile marine. Recently in the Dáil we had a debate in reference to the Port of Dublin and foreign coasting vessels. Year by year Irish-owned vessels are falling into foreign hands.

MainHeading.P: As a plain Irishman I think myself that until we begin to carry our own goods from abroad, and to carry goods we export from Ireland to other parts, this little nation can never go ahead as it should. Therefore, by instituting these guardships, if you like to call them that, you would do several things. You would help to avoid unemployment; you would provide sailors and fishermen for the nation, and you would protect your fisheries. I think it is rather a practical proposition that will have to be looked into very speedily. I believe that beneath the waves that surround our coast there lies as rich a harvest as there is beneath the soil of Ireland. It is not a question for any individual in the Government. It is a Governmental question, and, as I said, until some solution like that is brought about, we will not go ahead as a nation.

It is a well-known fact that the people of Ireland, per head, eat less fish than the people of any other nation. I think that if the virtues of fish as a food were explained to our people, and if an intensive campaign to explain the value of fish as a food were entered upon it would stimulate the public interest and, I hope, the appetite for fish. I realise that, perhaps, everything is not done that could be done to engender such a desire. I would suggest with great respect that when this fishing campaign is being launched—I am sure it will be very carefully thought out—first of all, the fishermen should be approached, under the co-operative scheme, and that in co-operation with the transport departments, the Great Southern and other railways, you would have established what are called fish trains. One thing to be remembered in regard to fish is that you must have it fresh. With, perhaps, the exception of milk, you are dealing with the most perishable food you could deal with. Therefore, you must have rapidity in transport both on the sea and up to the quayside, and from the quayside to the train, by means of motor lorries or other fast vehicles. The railways should be compelled, if necessary, to have suitable refrigerators or to have ice wagons, or whatever is necessary to bring fresh fish to the doors of the people in Dublin, Waterford and every city and town in Ireland. I believe if we are going to make this co-operative scheme a success there must be a certain amount of drive in it, a certain amount of intensity.

I have always looked upon the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Fisheries as twin Departments. I am not an agriculturist myself, but I take a very deep interest in fishing, and I feel very jealous when I find that you have something like £408,000 odd devoted to agriculture, and only £42,000 handed over to the Minister for Fisheries. I think somebody said here to-night that he regarded the fishery industry as the second most important industry in the State. I agree with that, and I think that all reasonable men must agree that you cannot do a lot of practical good on £42,000 a year. It is no use blaming the Minister for Fisheries. This is a national question, and one man cannot do very much. I am firmly of opinion that the great necessity at the present moment is adequate protection for the fisheries within the three mile limit of the Irish coastline. Unless you have that you are throwing your hat at it.

Some Deputy mentioned Russia. The most valuable fish in Ireland, with the exception of salmon, is, I think, herring. Russia, I understand, used to buy a good deal of our salted herring. Russia has been in a disturbed condition, though I do not know what state it is in now. I would certainly suggest the opening up of trade relations with Russia. If she is generous, and does not want us to give our produce to her and remain for too long out of the money—in other words, if it is not too much on the Kathleen Mavourneen style—I certainly would advocate the re-opening of trade relations with Russia. Of course, there are other countries, too, in the Frigid Zone—Poland, Finland, Germany, etc., which are very keen on fatty fish, such as herring. I would, with all respects, suggest to the Minister that trade relations be opened with these countries and that the curing, the branding and the grading of herrings be looked to at once. Of course, if there is no adequate protection for fishermen within the three-mile limit, everything comes to nought. As I said, I admire the Minister and his officials for the work they have done and are doing for the country. I am delighted to hear the Minister mentioning that he is going to go ahead with the co-operative movement.

Speaker.P: I am half ashamed to admit that I listened very attentively to the Minister's opening statement, because I have listened before to the Minister, and I read his speeches, and, even since the last time, I have read his speeches throughout the country and I cannot find that any of his promises have been carried out. It is not a bit surprising that Deputies who spoke on this side of the House have laid stress on the point that the Minister was a wonderful man for making promises and for not keeping them. On 28th February, 1927, the day before the Fishery Conference, he stated publicly that he had placed a scheme for the revaluation of boats before the Minister for Finance and that he was glad to say he had sanctioned it. On the Estimates last year, he said that the Bill was drafted. This is 1929, and we have not heard anything since about the revaluation of the boats. Great surprise has been evinced by Deputies as to why the Minister should not have proceeded with this scheme for the revaluation of boats. I pointed out to the Minister last year on the Estimates that his scheme for revaluation was useless. Boats valued at £600 and £800, taken from Arran and transferred to Galway and sold for 15/- are not worth revaluation. The remainder of the craft there, which he had to pay a caretaker 1/6 a week to mind, should be let rot, and the whole scheme for revaluation should have been dropped. Revaluation should have been dropped years ago. Four or five years ago it might have had some effect in Arran and Cleggan, and these places, but the revaluation promised in 1927 and last year was of no use to the fishermen who did own the boats at one time. That was the principal and only reason that, I suppose, the Minister did not carry out that scheme of revaluation. What I blame him for is that he did not know the boats had gone rotten and that the nets and fishing gear and the boats themselves were being sold for such ridiculous prices. A boat that cost £400 or £500 being sold for 12/6 or 15/-, and the highest price paid being £10, shows there was gross carelessness, that the Minister did not know his job, and that he did not look into it when he promised that he would get these boats revalued.

MainHeading.P: To-day the Minister made a statement about rural industries which, with other statements he made, goes to show that the Minister is not sincere when making promises that everything will be all right if we only pass the Estimate. He said to-day that the rural industry schemes in the West of Ireland were a burden on the public funds. Later he said that by starting a central depot for the sale of the articles produced here and relieving the manageresses of the onus of sales he could increase the wages and make them a paying proposition. Last year the central depot was discussed on the Gaeltacht White Paper, and it was definitely promised that there would be a central depot set up for the sale of cardigans and knitted work of all descriptions made in these schools. The central depot has not been set up since. What has happened? Only two or three weeks ago the Minister sent down an inspector and reduced the wages for knitting garments from 10d. to 6d. per garment. A girl working 14 hours per day will knit 30 cardigans per week and thus earn about 15/-. Those who do the measuring and seaming and pressing, etc., are paid much less: 1/3 for 16 cardigans for measuring, 9d. for seaming 8 cardigans; 9d. for button-holing and putting on buttons on 8 cardigans. If they came up here and did some button-holing I suppose they would make more money. That is a very mean way of dealing with the rural industries—to promise last year to start a central depot which he never started. He said that these industries are a burden on the State. These cardigans are sold for 6/9. The material and the labour employed costs 4/3. The knitter makes thirty cardigans a week and the profit on each cardigan is half-a-crown. How then can the Minister say that these rural industries in Connemara are a failure and a burden upon the State? If they are, it is due to officialism and nothing else. We are going ahead with them all the same. When the Minister starts a central depot he is going to increase the wages to what they were before. I only speak for a small area of ten miles square in my own district where there were six factories working under the old Congested Districts Board. Last year since the Minister promised a central depot three were closed down and the wages were reduced from one pound to fifteen shillings for a fourteen hours day. I do not think that that shows efficiency in the Department of the Ministry for Lands and Fisheries.

The Minister has control of the housing as far as the Gaeltacht is concerned. I have spoken on various occasions here on that subject and the Minister for Local Government has invariably put me off by the statement that the scheme is now to be dealt with by the Minister for Fisheries. Last year I put down a question and asked the Minister what he intended to do with the housing question in the Gaeltacht. Any Deputy who knows the housing conditions in the Gaeltacht knows that the question is as pressing there as in Dublin or Cork. He told me at that time that the heads of his Department were conferring with a view to coming to some decision as to future policy. That conference was to be over after the Christmas recess. I asked again in February the same question and I was to have an answer before Easter—they were still sitting. I asked did they keep on sitting regularly. They are now at least nine or ten months deciding as to what attitude the Government is to take in regard to housing, and we only hear the same bald statement that they have sat. We do not know what they are going to do or what decision they have come to.

Now with regard to rural industries, I do not believe the Minister is in earnest. I think I have proved he is not. As regards housing, I cannot believe he is in earnest; as regards fishing, and as regards the revaluation of boats, it is evident that he is not in earnest. As regards the whole Gaeltacht problem, how can we have any hope that anything is going to be done in the Gaeltacht when the three principal items that the Minister has to deal with—housing, rural industries, and fishing—are neglected and are regarded as a burden on the State. How can we, in these circumstances, expect anything from the Minister or his Department for the Gaeltacht?

Speaker.hpid: Seosamh O Mongáin Seosamh O Mongáin
Speaker.P: Tá sean-ráidht go dtagann maith as cáirde agus grásta as foighid. Ach ní fhéadfaidh duine ar bith a rá nách raibh foighid go leor ag lucht na Gaeltachta go dtí seo. Tá mé féin in ánn a rá go bhfuil maith eicínt le feiceál faoi dheire. An rud adubhairt an tAire faoi'n iascach, tá mé cinnte má chuireann sé leis sa mBille atá sé ag tabhairt isteach sa bhFoghmhar, go gcuirfidh sé cosaí faoi'n iascaireacht. Tá sé ag cur Cumann ar bun nách mbeidh dada le déanamh acu ach féachaint i ndiaidh an iascaigh. Beidh airgead faoi n-a gcúram. Is ortha a bhéas luach na mbád do thabhairt amach agus do chruinniú. Ní bheidh siad ag iarraidh duine ar bith i mbannaí. Im thuairim-se, is maith é seo mar go ndéanfaidh an bád agus an fhuireann íoc a luach ar ais.

Anuiridh, dubhairt mé rud eicínt faoi iasachtaí do thabhairt do lucht na mbád mbeag le gliomadóireacht agus a leithéid sin d'iascaireacht. Féadaim a rá nár chuala mé nár h-eitigheadh aon duine amháin acu seo faoi'n iasacht seo.

MainHeading.P: Anois, bhí caint mhór ag an muinntear taobh thall faoi mheas na mbád agus an gléas. Tá a fhios agam, roimh an gcogadh mhór, go bhfuighfí líon le h-aghaidh ronnachaí ar £2 5s. Od. Nuair a bhí an cogadh mór tamall beag ar siúl, chuaidh luach na líonta seo suas go dtí £21. An dream a bhí ann an t-am sin, ba chuma leo céard a dhéanfadh an t-íoc seo ar ais. Ní ar mhaithe dúinn-ne sin uilig; bhí siad ag iarraidh iase fhághailt dá gcuid saighdiúir a bhí ag troid. Agus nuair a fuair an tAire na báid agus na líonta seo ar ais ón tSasanach, nuair a bhí an cogadh thart, sé an tairgead mór a bhí ortha. Mar sin, caithfidh an tAire go leor den airgead do ghearradh amach.

Faoi'n gceilp, tá a fhios agam go bhfuil an tAire ag iarraidh a dhícheall, a dhéanamh ach déarfainn leis an dream thall nach bhfuil sé chó réidh an cheilp, a fhághailt ar a chosaibh agus a cheapann siad-san. Tá a fhios agam é seo, mar tá go leór agam le déanamh lei. Anois, faoi'n iascach in sna lochannaí, níl amhreas ann nách mó a rinneadh ó thainig sí faoi'n Aire ná rinneadh faoi réim an tSasanaigh riamh.

Speaker.P: Is fíor agus tá fhios ag duine ar bith go bhfuil colas aige faoi'n iascach seo gur fíor. Tá mé cinnte go gcuirfeadh sé feabhas mór ar an iascach dá mbeadh aibhneacha Chonamara faoi aon Bhord amháin.

MainHeading.P: Anois, faoi'n gceist is mó a bhaineas leis an nGaeltacht—ceist na dtithe. Is maith liom, faoi dheire, go bhfuil an tAire ag tabhairt Bille nua isteach. Tá a fhios agam go bhfuil an Cumanna atá ag obair i ngeall de'n Bhille seo—go bhfuil siad a dhéanamh a ndícheall agus go bhfuil a gcroidhe leis an nGaeltacht, mar bhí mé féin roimh an gCumann seo faoi'n gceist agus tá mé chó cinnte agus go bhfuil mé ag labhairt annseo go dtiocfaidh toradh maith as. Faoi láthair, tá ceann nua ag gabhail dhá gcur ar dheich dteach fhichead in Inis Bó Finne agus go leór tithe eile réidhtithe mar seo in oileáin eile le cúpla blian anuas.

Ba mhaith liom a chlú féin do thabhairt faoi'n Rúnaidhe nua go bhfuil baint aige leis an nGaeltacht. Gan amhreas, tá sé ag déanamh a dhícheall agus tá súil agam, sar i bhfad, go dtíocfaidh toradh maith as a chuid oibre.

Speaker.P: I want to repudiate the statement made here to-day that there has been anything done for the development of the inland fisheries by the Department of Fisheries. Since the inception of the Saorstát nothing has been done to clear the mouths of the rivers going into the lakes, with the result that trout cannot get up to the spawning beds. Men who make their living at these lakes will tell you that. Nothing has been done to improve conditions there to allow the trout to make their way up to the spawning beds. What has been done on the following lakes, Derravagh, Glore, Lane and Sheehan? Something may have been done on the Pike Pond at Mullingar, but that does not indicate that in the main locks anything has been done.

I should like to draw the attention of the Minister to the fact that serious consideration has been given to the reduction in the Estimates for the Minister's Department since 1925 and 1926, largely because of the fact that we have a reduction also in the population along the coast in the Gaeltacht districts throughout the country. It is no wonder when we have no money at the disposal of the Fisheries Department or when the fishery industry is not developed that we should have serious depopulation along the coast. The Gaeltacht Commission was established in 1925 and as a result of that inquiry many recommendations have been placed before the Department of Fisheries for its consideration and its adoption, and foremost amongst them was one for the revaluation of the boats the fishermen had at the time and which were valued at the inflated prices that ruled in 1921 and 1922. Before the Commission there was placed what was called recommendation 30. Since that period we have been continually promised that this recommendation would get consideration like many of the others that were placed before the Fisheries Department. He quoted from what the Department themselves have to say about the matter. I will read the paragraph. The Fisheries Report for 1923-1925 states:—

“The position of these large loans and the accumulation of heavy arrears has become one of the most serious problems confronting the Department of Fisheries which is consulting with the Department of Finance in order to find a way out. It is evident that the position of hopeless indebtedness under which many of our fishermen are labouring does not create a condition favourable to the rapid development of the industry.”

MainHeading.P: It appears that they have been since finding a way out, and, like Moses, I am afraid they are in the dark yet, because it is quite evident that nothing has come from all the recommendations and promises we have got from the Department since 1923. In his opening statement the Minister mentioned communications with islanders. Some time ago on the West Mayo coast extreme difficulties were experienced by some islanders who had been isolated owing to the continuous storms along the coast. The people were actually starving, and things had become so bad that the Government were commissioned to send down the “Muirchu” to bring some relief to the place. That took three or four weeks. The result was that people were in a most pitiable plight on those islands. I put a question a year ago or more about that particular difficulty and the Minister stated that the matter was getting consideration. It is like the other deferred questions which have been getting consideration for some years past It is very serious, and I trust even now that it will get attention, and that the coming winter will see that the people on the islands off our coast will be able to get some relief if such difficulties occur as have occurred during the past two years.

I notice that in many places around the coast the salmon fishermen are anxious to have the season for salmon opened earlier. Requests have been made to promote legislation to that end, and so far no result in the Department has been brought about. I would like to impress on the Minister that is really deserving of consideration, because salmon appear apparently much earlier than they did when the fishery laws were instituted, perhaps centuries ago. It is very important that the fishermen should be given permission to start salmon fishing earlier along the coast.

On the Afforestation Vote the other day, the Minister for Agriculture, when I put the point to him about planting in West Mayo, said that there was very little land in Mayo fit for afforestation. I would like to refer the Minister for Finance to the fact that all over the coast we can point out the tree stumps of ancient forests which we had in Mayo. I think that should be an encouragement for him to try and replace those old trees which existed in former days. Their existence in the past, I think, is evidence that there is a possibility of the same occurring in the future if only an attempt were made to replace them. I think they would thrive, and it is worth a chance. We were promised also by the Minister, in his opening speech to-day, that the people in the Gaeltacht would get encouragement for the building of houses. I hope his promise, unlike past promises, will be given effect to. I am anxious to know how soon we are going to have funds made available for that purpose, because, up to the present, the House has not been approached for a Vote on that particular issue. I do not see how anything can be done in the fall of the coming year or the winter, in that respect. If anything is to be done in the near future, it is time that the House should be approached and that a Vote should be requested for this particular Department.

Deputy Sheehy referred to our programme. It is not for us to formulate a programme for the Department of Fisheries. After all, that is their particular job. It is ours to see and criticise the working of that Department. Deputy Sheehy, I think, must be under some delusion if he suggests that it is our place to formulate a programme for the Minister. As I say, it is his business, and he should see to it and give us some results in the near future instead of promises.

Speaker.P: Deputy Dr. White expressed admiration for the Minister and the work he has done in his Department. If Deputy Dr. White was speaking of some performance that the Minister was about to do, I would say that Deputy Dr. White was a super-optimist; but looking at the work that has not been done by the Minister in the past, and having been on a couple of deputations to the Minister's Department, I will borrow a motto from Dante, and will nail it up on the door of the Department of Fisheries: “Abandon hope all ye who enter here.” For the last five or six years—not alone has the Minister not done anything to help fisheries, but he has left them in a very much worse position than they were when he started. We had put up questions in the House, and every time they were brought up they were met by the Minister in a manner that would lead ordinary outside people to believe that as far as fisheries were concerned, the Minister was in the kindergarten class.

MainHeading.P: The other day we were talking about territorial waters. The Minister stated that if they are territorial waters they belong to us. Another time I had a question put. I asked the Minister why he did not collect the fines that were imposed on foreign trawlers, and the Minister made the answer in this wise: “I have no jurisdiction outside the Saorstát,” said the Minister. Foolish Charlie knows that the Minister has no jurisdiction outside the Saorstát. He need not have come here to tell us that. What I want to know is, has the Minister any jurisdiction inside the Saorstát, and that if there were trawlers encroaching inside the three-mile limit, and if they were fined, why these fines were not collected. “I have no jurisdiction outside the Saorstát,” says the Minister. But if the trawlers got within the three-mile limit, and if they were fined £100, and if that money was never collected, what I want to know is— has the Minister any jurisdiction inside the Free State? He talked about looking for extra territorial waters. We do not want them. We can dispense with them. What we want is our own. If there are territorial waters that belong to us, if there is a trawler arrested for poaching within the three-mile limit, I take it it is inside the territorial waters, and as I said, I take it it is not entitled to fish inside that limit. Why then is not the trawler detained until the fine is obtained? If it happened in any other country in the world it would be detained, they would fine the skipper, and if, he did not pay they would simply sell his boat and gear.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister responsible for the collection of fines?
The Minister should be responsible for the protection of fisheries inside the three-mile limit.
Is the Minister responsible for the collection of fines?

Probably he is not. I bow to your ruling. At the same time the Minister is responsible for the patrol boat that is supposed to protect the fishermen around the coast of the Saorstát. We have had repeated complaints from Donegal that foreign trawlers are coming in there and poaching with their registration numbers camouflaged with canvas. A schoolboy, if he had a rifle, could arrest a boat and take her into port. This glorified sardine tin that we have patrolling the coast of the Saorstát — the “Muirchu”—I do not know what it is doing, although we are spending upwards of £8,000 a year on it. Any child could at any time off the coast of Fanit Head have arrested any of these trawlers for illegal fishing. After all, a helmsman is not armour-plated. If you sent a schoolboy out with a rifle a helmsman on a trawler has to cave in whether he likes it or not, unless they are going to erect a special steel casing for him. We have this beautiful boat, the “Muirchu”; we are spending £8,000 a year on it. The suggestion was made by Deputy Mullins that if they got a few fast motor launches and gave power to the local fishery inspectors, in co-operation with the Civic Guards, to be armed, they could do all that is necessary, and you would not require this patrol boat at all because it is only a white elephant as far as we are concerned.

MainHeading.P: Turning to the question of the several fisheries that we debated last Friday, the question as a whole is one which should receive the attention of the Minister. It is not to the credit of any country that a few people, with very doubtful vested interests, should control hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of fisheries both in the inland and tidal waters of the Saorstát. It means that in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred people who are deriving a huge income from the several fisheries of the Saorstát are spending it outside this country. I quoted the instance of one company, only one member of which resided in Ireland, the rest of the company being domiciled in England. As a matter of fact, the manager of the company did not even know the members of the company. The one member of the company who resides in Ireland resides in the Six Counties. They are making an annual income of something like £9,000, and that money is being spent in England. Monte Carlo, or somewhere else. The fishermen who are depending on the fisheries for a livelihood and who would spend the money accrued from the fisheries on themselves and their families in this country are denied the right of earning their livelihood. Hence the big emigration. Over six thousand in a few years went from Donegal. If the Minister wants to give an opportunity to the fishermen along the seaboard he should tackle this question of the several fisheries with all the resources he has at his command. Do not leave it to the individual fisherman to do what the Government should be doing. It was always the way with Government Departments, and particularly with the Department of Fisheries, to shove a job on somebody else. The poor fishermen are not in a position to fight big, expensive lawsuits. They could not do it and it is up to the Ministry to do it.

The Minister gave us an analogy the other day. It was about the most silly performance that I have ever listened to in my life. He said that if a man is using implements on a farm which he claims to be his. but which are not his, and the real owner or the man who thinks he is the real owner comes along, his obvious remedy is to go to the police. Very good. I will take the Minister up on that. It hinges on this very question. What we were discussing at the particular time was the question of the fishery in the Foyle. I put up a contention that even granted that the Foyle and Bann Company were the legal owners of the several fisheries of the Foyle, that they still were not entitled to bring armed men there from another State to seize gear belonging to fishermen from the peninsula of Inishowen. Taking the Minister up on his own analogy, would not it have been a proper thing for the Foyle and Bann Company to have come along to the fishery inspector in Moville and to the Civic Guards and said: “Here are people fishing illegally on a several fishery which is our property, and which we hold according to charter”?

Speaker.P: Not necessarily. They have the powers under the Larceny Act to seize fishery gear and to use whatever powers are necessary. I am not saying anything as to whether or not that involves the use of arms. I myself think it does not.
The Board of Conservators issued licences to these men whose nets were seized. What position does that put them in?
Was not all this matter discussed on Friday?
I submit we are entitled to discuss everything in connection with the Fisheries Department on this Vote.
The Deputy is not entitled to indulge in repetition.

Granted that any proprietors of a several fishery are entitled to use force for the seizure of gear which is being used illegally on what they term their own possessions, at the same time they are not entitled to import armed forces from another State. That is the crux of the whole thing. We have had a series of promises from the Minister since we came in here—for almost two years—and I have yet to see any of those promises carried out. A very important thing—it has been referred to several times in the debate here to-day—was the revaluation of boats and gear. The Minister promised us eighteen months ago that the question of revaluation would be dealt with practically immediately.

MainHeading.P: Not longer ago than about two months I had here the case of a man who was unable to pay up his instalments. The Department was coming down on him with a very heavy hand indeed. These boats and gear were issued at a time when boats cost perhaps three times what they would cost now. The same applies to the gear. There were numbers of the fishermen who had actually paid half the cost of the boats and gear. The boats and gear were seized from them because they could not pay up the instalments. They found themselves in this position: that the break came and they could not pay their instalments. The prices of fish went down, and the fishing was bad four to seven years ago. These men had got their gear and boats during the time of the war. After that time fish were scarce and prices were bad, and the fishermen discovered that they were not able to keep up the instalments. In a number of cases the Ministry of Fisheries came down on these men like a ton of bricks. They did not give them a dog's chance.

Speaker.P: Give a few instances.

I will give one. I gave the Minister one twelve months ago. That was the case of the brothers Hegarty, who got a boat valued at £3,000. They paid up £1,500 of that money and then the Department took back the boat.
And I told the Deputy at the time that the Hegartys had asked that the boat be taken from them.

Is that any justification? They were manly enough. These men got a boat valued at £3,000. They were hardy fishermen, and they paid £1,500 of the £3,000. They were manly enough to ask the Minister to take up the boat when the prices fell and when fishing was bad all over the country. But was that any justification for what the Minister did? If these men had paid that money on furniture in a shop they would have got some consideration. They would have been left with some part of that furniture for which they had paid £1,500. What did they get from the Minister? Up to the present they have got nothing. That is one instance. If the Minister wants any more instances I can give them, but I do not want to dwell on this too long.
Go on and give them.

There is another thing that comes under the Department of Fisheries and, of course, it is the usual round of promises. Eighteen months ago there was an inspector appointed for the purpose of giving a filip to the homespun industry in Donegal. At that time we were told this inspector had all the qualifications necessary to help the industry there. According to the the Minister, there was a Central bureau to be started somewhere in Ardara. When all these cloths of different patterns were made under the auspices of the Department and under the supervision of this inspector, and when that stuff would arrive, it would be stamped with the Government stamp. Precautions would be taken by the Government to market the product in the best possible way. In October last the Minister told us that all these things would be under way in about four months' time. I am still waiting to hear what has happened in the case of that inspector. I have had no trace whatsoever of any activity on his part. I have had communications from people in Ardara, from people who are intimately connected with this particular industry, people who have taken a keen interest in it and people who have its future at heart, and they have failed to hear of anything that has been done by the inspector. Ardara was to have been his headquarters, his principal centre, and still the people there know absolutely nothing about his activities.

MainHeading.P: The Minister might tell us that the inspector who was appointed produced a certain class of cloth of different patterns and that they were put into a room down here in the Department of Fisheries. I say to the Minister that that is all bunkum. What we want in Donegal is not a few samples in a room in the Department of Fisheries, but something real and tangible as a result of the appointment of that inspector. The Committee in Ardara offered to put up £600 by way of helping the Government in installing certain machinery. As a matter of fact, in their electrical plant run by waterpower they made special provision for its adaptation to the factory for the purpose of carding, breaking and dyeing the wool. But what has the Minister done? Those people offered to put up portion of the money. Has the Minister done anything up to the present? The Minister said: “Send your wool to the Convoy Woollen Mills and get it treated there.” The people wrote to him from Ardara and told him that they had already sent the wool to the Convoy Woollen Mills and that it had been returned untouched. The people there asked the Minister: “Give us some help and we will do the rest towards establishing the factory for the purpose of treating wool here in Ardara.” But what has the result been? The Department said: “There is a Scotch firm negotiating about a place in Ardara, or somewhere near Ardara, to set up a factory for this purpose.”“Come all you Scotchmen, Englishmen, Germans, anybody; come all you and do the work, and we in the Ministry of Fisheries will do nothing. Scotchmen, come along and do what we should have been doing for the last five years.” Does anybody in this House mean to tell me that we are looking for the best results for the country when we expect, and wish and hope that some Scotchman or some German or somebody else will come along and do what we are supposed to be doing here ourselves? The people of Ardara, the old spinners of Donegal, want to know what the Minister is doing about it.

The Minister need not make any elaborate promises in the future, because the people have had so many promises from him that they take them all now with a grain of salt. This inspector went to the houses two years ago; he interviewed all the old spinners, and he came to the conclusion, evidently, that spinning as an industry was practically dead in Donegal. Well, it is not dead, but if no help is forthcoming from the Department it will be dead very soon. The new clip of wool could not be dealt with. They were holding it over, expecting from day to day that the Minister would wake up and do something, tangible for the industry, but now they have come to the conclusion that the new clip of wool will take the place of the old, that is, the old clip that was returned from the Convoy woollen mills untouched. The consequence will be that the whole industry will collapse. Of course the Minister had some bouquets thrown at him to-day from his own benches, but the Minister had some pungent criticisms from these benches, and they were deserved very much. If the Minister does not wake up and do something really worth while, I for one will be the first to vote, if such a vote were proposed, for the extermination of the whole Department of Fisheries. As far as we can gather, looking at the results for the last five years, this Department is only a white elephant. Not alone should the Vote be reduced, but the Vote for this Department should be wiped out altogether.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Jordan Mr. S. Jordan
Speaker.P: On the 21st November, 1928, I addressed the following question to the Minister for Lands and Fisheries: “To ask the Minister for Lands and Fisheries whether he received a copy of a resolution passed by the Galway Urban District Council requesting the establishment of a fishing school in the Galway urban area for the Claddagh fishermen, and, if so, what action it is intended to take in the matter.” The Minister replied: “I have received a copy of the resolution referred to. Proposals for the establishment of a small number of preparatory schools along the lines of paragraph 229 of the Report of the Commission on Technical Education, for providing suitable education and training for boys likely to be engaged in the fishing industry, and for the appointment, as suggested in paragraph 231 of the same Report, of itinerant instructors to conduct short courses of instruction for part-time fishermen, are at present being examined by my Department and the Department of Education. In this connection the claims of the district referred to in the question have not been overlooked.”

MainHeading.P: The way I desire to put it is that the Twenty-six Counties, not to mind Galway, heard nothing at all about fishing until the 20th May, 1929. In the morning's papers on the 20th of last May we were told that the Minister for Fisheries mentioned in the Sligo-Leitrim election that he was going to make this isle a paradise for fishermen. It took from November, 1928, to the Sligo-Leitrim election to bring relief to the fishermen. A promise was made them and the bait went down. It obtained the result that they asked for. The paper said: “Return General Seán McKeon and the fishermen of Ireland are safe.” He is returned now, and up to the present he has not contributed much to the Fisheries Vote. We request the Minister to put his promises into operation. If I were in Deputy McKeon's place I would demand that the Minister would carry out his promise, because it would save my face for being sent here on the pretence that it was going to be done. That was the 20th May.

By a remarkable coincidence, in the week from the 1st to the 7th July in Connemara, where something should be done by the Fisheries Department in face of the promises made last November and during the Sligo-Leitrim election, a letter was sent from the Department to Canon McAlpine closing down the only industry in the district. The Congested Districts Board had a school there known as the lace school. The building in which the classes were conducted was given rent free to the Fisheries Department. The Department wrote down as follows: “After full consideration the Minister is forced to the conclusion that the cost to the State of maintaining this centre does not justify its retention, and I am accordingly to inform you that it has been decided to close it down.”

I do not propose to delay the House, because I think sufficient criticism has been meted out if it has any effect. I suppose it will not have effect this year any more than any other year. I would like the Minister to state definitely when he is going to put his promise of the 21st November into effect, as regards the establishment of a small number of preparatory schools for fishery training for boys. Is there such a scheme in the great programme that we were promised on May 20th or is it in the big programme with which he opened up this Vote? I also want to know from him is it his intention to adhere to this letter and to throw forty or fifty young girls in the Gaeltacht out of employment and tell them to go to America if they want to?

Speaker.P: Where did the Deputy get the figures forty or fifty?
I will read for you what is stated here: “A score of girls were employed.”
A score would not represent forty or fifty. Employment was given in Clifden school to two girls and a few out-workers.

I will quote my authority. The first part of the report I have deals with the Cleggan fishery. It states that some two or three years ago as much as three train-loads of fish per week used to leave for Galway. There were innumerable carts carting fish, and Cleggan was one of the best fishing centres in western Ireland. To-day the people cannot get a living. Is that right?
Am I responsible for the mackerel again not coming near the coast at Cleggan?

You are the Minister for Fisheries. I am not saying that you are responsible for the mackerel not coming there, but you ought to be responsible for the way the fisher-folk in that area are treated. There are French trawlers coming there. To my knowledge a French trawler was detained in Galway Bay and the Department was telegraphed from Galway by the Superintendent of the Civic Guards. An answer went back to release the trawler. That was during the election in June, 1927.
That does not come within this Estimate.
I know, but the Minister can make inquiries and see if I am not saying what is right. He was responsible for that.
Even if it were a trawler it had nothing whatever to do with the mackerel. It would not affect the mackerel.
It had something to do with the fisher-folk there. These people can poach the fish, but the fisherman in Galway cannot get a living.

The letter referring to the lace school says: “This industry gave employment to between 15 and 20 girls, who work from patterns submitted by the instructress; they work on them in their own homes.” The Minister spoke about giving employment only to two girls. I would like to know if the Department insists on the closing down of this industry. Is that the way they are going to put into effect the suggestions of the Gaeltacht Commission, to secure employment for the people? Are they going to throw a score of girls out of employment, and tell them that they can go with the thousands of others who have left Galway to seek a living through the emigrant ship?

In discussing this Estimate we feel we are rushed, because we want to have some little time for the discussion of the Appropriation Bill afterwards. I certainly think that if there is one Estimate that should have been considered to the full it is this Estimate of the Department of Fisheries. We do not grumble at all at voting £77,500 to the Department of Fisheries. We would not grumble if this money were going to be well spent, but we have no belief that this money will be well spent. Certainly, from the action of the Department in the past, and from the action of the Government generally in relation to fisheries, we have no hope that this £77,500 is going to be any good to the fishing population of Ireland. There are one or two matters of detail that I want to bring to the Minister's attention. The Minister says that he is going to bring in a Bill here to revalue the boats that were given out some years ago.

I have a letter here that was sent out from the Minister's Department on the 4th July to people in Clogher Head, threatening them that if they did not immediately pay their arrears of loans the Minister was going to institute proceedings for recovery without further notice. That was sent both to the owners and the guarantors. It is not much help to people to have letters of that kind coming along disturbing them, particularly as the Minister's Department is to a large extent responsible for some of the arrears. These people were to have got a boat in April, but it was delivered three months afterwards, when the fishing season was practically over. There is another great cause for complaint, and I think that the Minister should either give way to the fisherman or get his experts to go into the matter and issue some sort of notice to the fishermen again. I refer to the question of opening the fishing season earlier. A lot of fishermen along the Boyne urge that they should be allowed to fish a month earlier and that the season should be closed a month earlier. They say that it would do no harm to the fishing, but would be a great boon to them. Fishermen all over the country have, I understand, the same complaint to make.

MainHeading.P: As I have said, we are not objecting so much to paying £77,500 for this Department, but we would have no objection to paying ten times that amount if we thought that it would be properly spent. We do not, however, believe that it is going to be properly spent. We fear that in the next census returns it will be shown that the Irish population has again been cut down by half, as it was cut down by half during the two previous census periods. The Government, on the whole, have done nothing for the Gaeltacht areas or for the fishing population. If they were a real national Government, one of the first steps they would take would be to keep the fishing population from emigrating. In every country where there is a good national Government, the section of the community that they look after first is the fishing folk. They are a great asset to any nation and they would be a great asset to Ireland if they were encouraged. One reason why I would like to see this Government kicked out is that they have failed to deal with the situation in the Gaeltacht and with fishing generally. I hope it will not be long until they are kicked out and until some Government comes in that will appoint a proper Minister for Fisheries and give him a proper sum to deal with the whole subject.

Speaker.P: The first point raised by Deputy de Valera was with reference to the External Loan, and as to what steps have been taken in that regard. No steps have been taken, because the receivers or liquidators appointed by the courts to deal with the sums in America, which were the subject of litigation there, have not finished their work. It will not be possible for us to make arrangements about paying the remainder of the loan until these officials have completed their task, and until the books and records are available for us. I have said before that we regard the whole debt as a liability on the State, and our attitude is not affected by the decision of the American Courts in any way in regard to it. Deputy de Valera asked about the question of the return of token coinage, and mentioned that the token coinage was part of the national debt of the United Kingdom, and that therefore all responsibility in connection with that coinage fell to be a liability of the British Government. One of the difficulties in dealing with this whole question of token coinage is that it is not redeemable legally. There is no legal obligation on the Mint to take token coinage back. There is no legal obligation on anybody to receive more than £2 in silver, so that the whole thing ought to be dealt with, not on the question of legal, but of moral responsibility.

There was undoubtedly as between the banks or private individuals here holding token coinage and the British Government, a very clear moral responsibility on the part of the British Government. If, for instance, the coinage were to become useless here and cease to be legal tender here for any amount, and to become worthless in the hands of the holders here, then they would have a clear moral claim against the British Government, as undoubtedly that coinage had been paid for in butter, cattle, eggs and other products by the people of this country. As between the Government of the Saorstát and the British Government the matter was to some extent complicated by other considerations, considerations which really did not apply in the cases of South Africa and Australia. At the time of the issue of the coinage there had been a joint Exchequer, and it could be argued that this country had got already its share of the benefits from the issue of the coinage. I need not really attempt to retrace all the arguments that were used on both sides.

MainHeading.P: The position was that in South Africa and in Australia, where, if anything, there was a stronger case for the repatriation by the British Government of the coinage, the arrangement made was that it should be repatriated over a number of years. Of course those countries had not the type of financial dealings that we have with the British Government, the payment of certain sums in respect of pensions and other matters. There was perhaps less reason in their case for dealing with the whole matter at once. It was perhaps more reasonable in their case that the payment should be spread over a period of years than in our case, where sums were being paid from one Government to the other for a substantial amount. Nevertheless there was the fact that repatriation had been accomplished over a period of years. Consequently it could not be held that the British Government had repudiated their liability, their liability being, as I said, not a legal liability but a moral liability. It could not be said that the British Government repudiated that liability. If they dealt with the matter more generously they might have effected repatriation at once, but there are certainly no grounds for saying that they dealt with the matter in the spirit of dishonouring a cheque.

If they did deal with the matter in the spirit of dishonouring a cheque, there would have been measures available to us which would not be justified when the course that was taken by the British Government was actually taken. If they had entirely repudiated liability there were certain remedies which I had in mind, but I could not feel any justification in resorting to those remedies after the demands of the Saorstát were met on lines parallel to the stronger demand that had been made by countries like South Africa and Australia. There is no point, when debating matters like this, in Deputies talking about this Government being bluffed by the British Government and all the things done by them. It is very easy for Deputy de Valera to talk in that way when he took good care that he would have no responsibility.

Speaker.P: Were you one of those who voted for it?
